Hi there, my name is Thomas Lam. I'm an aspiring software developer. Keep scrolling to read more about my bio and side projects.

About

I'm a CS major at Amherst College. In my free time, I develop web and iOS apps. My portfolio is still expanding so look forward to my future projects! When I'm not programming, I like to listen to music (classical, pop, EDM), read books (mostly fiction, contemporary and classics) and doodling. Some of my other interests include jogging, alpine skiing and rowing.

Why CS?

My interest in computer science and programming started in my junior year of high school, when I took AP computer science, my first foray into the world of programming. After passing the AP exam, I was determined to learn more on my own about computer science and coding. So I took it upon myself to complete independent computer science projects. There were times when I thought I couldn't finish these projects, but to my surprise I persevered and actually completed them. Along with the satisfaction that came with completing projects that I thought I couldn't do, I also had a better grasp of object oriented programming and learned about best coding practices which I never could have learned in a traditional computer science class.

After my senior year, I decided to apply to MakeGamesWithUs Summer Academy program (now MakeSchool) since I have always wanted to develop an iOS game. It was the best decision I have made. Not only did I learn to be proficient in a new language Objective C and using new tools for iOS game development like XCode, Cocos2D and Spritebuilder, I gained new friendships with incredibly talented people and got valuable insights into the start-up scene at Silicon Valley. It was the best summer in my life so far. My experience at MGWU convinced me that a career in software development is the right track for me.

Projects

Progress

March 2015

A small todo web app displaying visual progress of current tasks using Twilio.

View

Rock, Paper, Myo

August 2014

This is my first hackathon project. I made this with four other talented developers and designer at YCHacks 2014 at Y Combinator office. This is also my first hack that I needed to figure out how to integrate a third-party API into code that I'm already familiar with. In this iOS game, the player, wearing Myo gesture control armband, can use different hand gestures to counter randomly generated moves during a time limit, with each win further extending the limit or each loss further shortening the limit correspondingly. The goal of the game is to have as many wins as possible before time runs out.

VIEW ON CHALLENGEPOST

God of Golf

June-August 2014

This is my first iOS game. I made this at MakeSchool Summer Academy. It's a physics based launching/puzzle-solving game. Your objective is to swipe your ball into the end hole. But there will be obstacles in the way. You can use special items from the item menu and drop and rotate them to your liking onto the golf course. They will help redirect the ball's path.

VIEW ON APP STORE

MazeApplet

January-March 2014

The program randomly generates a maze with dimensions specified by the user everytime it starts. The algorithm for generating the maze is Kruskal's algorithm. If you think of a maze as a group of rooms whose adjacent walls may or may not be "broken down" (first case means that two rooms are connected and thus there exists a path between the rooms), then the problem of generating a solvable maze becomes a simple task of randomly "kicking down" walls ensuring that a minimum spanning tree exists in this connected undirected graph. With this method of random generation, I also simplify the task of solving the puzzle. The solving algorithm I use is simple Depth First Search. The player can traverse the maze using the arrow keys or let the AI show the solution path. The data structure I use for grouping the rooms together is disjoint data set.

VIEW ON GITHUB

ConnectFour

September-November 2013

February 2015

My first CS side project. This is a Java computer simulation of Connect Four boardgame. Player can either play against another human player or computer AI. The algorithm for the computer AI is Minimax algorithm. My evaluation heuristics is basically counting all the possible combinations of "fours" given a specific location on the grid and putting these numbers in a 6x7 matrix. The AI attempts to move given the current board such that it maximizes the occupation of locations with most combinations of fours.

VIEW ON GITHUB

UPDATE: I've rewritten the game using HTML, CSS, Javascript (AngularJS and jQuery).
